messageBody:
javainsel wrote:
> I think that as a JUnit/TDD user you write tests 50% of the time you
> write code. Thats a lot.

Actually, I find that I'm spending even *larger* amounts of time working
with my tests. I haven't measured, but I'd have to guess around 70%.

And if I look at that number, it scares the hell out of me: 70% of my
coding time doing "non-production" work.

BUT.....

I've used JUnit regularly for the last year, after having not used any
kind of regular testing tool for the many years of development before that.

AND....

I am *FAR* more productive at producing working software now with JUnit
than I ever was before. The time spent working with tests

a) Saves me oodles of time implementing my features. Once the test
defines what I need to do, I write it. Once *all* of the tests work, my
feature is done. No more guessing about boundary conditions, unexpected
consequences, etc....
b) Creates much better (in particular, decoupled) code. This makes
subsequent bug fixes/enhancements far easier to implement.
c) Allows me to fix bugs fearlessly and cleanly rather than having to
add lots of "if-then" conditions around my bugs to try to isolate the
conditions causing the bugs.

THEREFORE...

Yes, I spend HUGE amount of time working with my tests. And that time
has *MORE* than paid for itself. Several times over, I'd guess. I'll
never develop again without that investment in testing.

FINALLY...

I don't think DBC or JUnit are different in this regard. I view both of
these as tools that formalize the contract of your methods/objects.
Both of them take a lot of time to set up and maintain (I feel it would
be naive to expect contracts to write or maintain themselves for any but
the most trivial methods).

So with either approach, be prepared to invest a significant amount of
time outside "traditional" production coding. But be prepared to get
huge return on that time.
